There is the skeleton of a whale in the courtyard and a couple of huts of the Nicobarese. A souvenir shop is available, surprisingly reasonably priced, to buy small knick knacks to remind you of your trip. A must visit location. More

title: Comprehensive Showcase
review_text: Samudrika Museum is located opposite to Andaman Teal House at Port Blair. It has the best collection of live ornamental sea fishes, specimens of various corals, clamshell and conches in whole Andamans. It also have various models and informative boards on living lifestyle of Andaman and Nicobar archipelago. A audio visual show on history and culture of Andamans is run continuously for the tourist. A well preserved Skeleton of Blue Whale is displayed here. The museum is well presented and managed by Indian Navy. Museum also has a small curio shop with some unique show pieces for sale. Though the prices are in higher side, once compared with Govt Managed Sagarika outlet for shells and Pearls products or Souvenir shop of Chatham Saw Mill for wooden products. There is a small entry fee for visitors, however, for going to Curio Shop directly; one may not pay any entry fee at the gate. Tell the gateman your purpose is solely to go to shop and he will not insist for any entry ticket. More

title: Well Maintained small Museum!
review_text: The Samudrika museum is located at a distance of about 3 km from Veer Savarkar Airport and takes not more than 15 minutes to reach here. The museum is open everyday except on Monday and Government holidays from 09:00 AM to 05:00 PM with 1 hr as lunch break from 01:00 PM. They charge a reasonable entry amount of Rs. 50 for adults and Rs. 25 for children in age group of 5 to 12 years. The museum is maintained and run by Indian Navy and has free entry to handicaps, freedom fighters and senior citizens ( A&N Islands) on showing a valid ID proof. The lawns of the museums are well maintained and cleanliness is given a prime importance. The museum has 5 different sections giving information about history of Andaman islands, original people of Andaman, geography of Andaman, archaeological exhibits and marine life. The museum offers a great insight about various aspects of Andaman islands and also has a good collection of various corals, shells and other remain of aquatic animals. Overall it is a good place to spent around 2 hrs and at same time gain information about the beautiful islands of Andaman and Nicobar. More

title: Discover the underwater world
review_text:
Samudrika Marine Museum is located right at the heart of Port Blair town and houses some fine exhibits of sub-marine species . Welcoming you as you enter the place is a full and complete skeleton of a blue whale which is the largest mammal on the planet. There are a few life size figures of Jarawa tribals on the other side giving the place a strong local flavour and emphasizing the fact that the island chain had been inhabited by tribal people much before the " civilized" outsiders such as British and Japanese set foot on the land. Different types of exhibits and posters are displayed in several sections , the most interesting of them being the coral and shell section. The aquarium section displays colorful tropical fish, sea urchin etc., 

A documentary film is on continuous display in the foyer showing different aspects of Andamans and the huge variety of places of tourist interest , notably the Havelock island, Jolly Buoy island, Neil Island etc.,The documentary is superbly produced and the Government would do well to make it available for a price on a CD . The museum also houses a shop selling souvenirs made of coral and shells besides some garments. It would take probably an hour to go round and get a good feel of the place and also obtain a while lot of useful info about the Islands. More

title: Small but marvellous museum worth seeing.
review_text: This museum in Port Blair has a good collection of artefacts and great historical information about the Andaman Islands. This place is run and maintained by the Indian Navy. A fee applies for entry but it is well worth it. The most interesting thing you will see when you come into the museum is the skeleton remains of a blue whale that was washed up on one of the islands some time ago. There is also a collection of coral fossils, sea shells and clothes and equipment used by various tribes that live in the Andaman Islands. This is a good place to understand their way of life without having to go and see them in person, which at this moment is not allowed. There is also a small but well kept aquarium housing any fishes and sea creatures that live in the Indian Ocean surrounding the Islands, provided you with interesting sea life without getting your feet wet. All exhibitions have their own descriptions and are self explanatory. There is also a small video presentation with comfortable benches explaining the history and life around the Andaman Islands both in Hindi and English, ideal for both locals and tourists who come and visit this place. title: This is the place to start your Andaman Trip
review_text:
It's nothing like you will find something exceptional here, but, just through the way it collects and presents information to you about the Islands is something that should make you explore first thing in Port Blair. 

Main contents of Samudrika: 
1. A quick 30 min video on Andaman history (available on youtube also but I reco you to watch it here) 
2. A section on Coral Reefs - interesting facts and 100+ variety 
3. A small sized aquarium - around 50 fishes but new ones - did not see them usually in any other aquarium. 
4. Smart kiosks kept at various places to browse an easy to understand catalogue about places & reasons to visit those places in Andamans. 
5. A section on tribal world of Andamans (did not interest me but would make sense to relevant people) 

What really clicks is when you see a fish in your scuba dive in the seas and you say I saw it in Samudrika and read about it. 

Must start your Andaman trip from here - would be well spent 2-3 hours with a couple of nice clicks as well. More

title: The counterclockwise conch
review_text: This very interesting exhibit is likely to be missed or overlooked . The vast majority of Snails species have shells that turn clockwise . Within a species that has clockwise shells it is very rare to find a shell turning the other way . This is called a torsional embryonic error and the mutation is not fully understood . These snails have great difficulty in breeding as their genitalia do not line up properly to normal snails . Since they cannot pass on the trait by breeding , such snails are probably the result of freak mutation and are likely to remain extremely rare oddities . Please look at the exhibit in this light . On the other hand , such snails escape from snail eating snakes as their mouth parts are designed to suck out regular clockwise snails . More

title: Gorgeous Gem of Andaman

Samudrika Marine Museum is under the control and management of the Indian Navy. It is situated at Delanipur in Andaman. The object of this museum is for generating awareness among the visitor about the environment in the ocean and the marine life. There are five sections namely 1. History of Andaman Islands, 2. Geographical information, 3. About people of Andaman, 4. Archaeology and 5. About Marine life. There are wide collections of corals, shells and fish fauna. It is a treasury of worthy marine life, particularly of rare fish species. These are treasure trove items that offer imperative information to the tourists regarding the history and geography of the Andaman Islands. The Samudrika Marine Museum is also known as the Naval Marine Museum is just on the opposite side of Andaman Teal House in Delanipur. The maritime animals displayed here are said to be more than 350 diverse varieties of ocean resources. The crocodiles, sharks, dolphins, prawns and crabs are worthy of viewing in this museum. It has a wonderful collection of corals, shells and other momentous specimens of the marine life characteristic of these islands. We can see the excellent collection of fishes of unusual colours. There are quite a lot of fascinating facts about the region and the maritime culture. Samudrika Marine Museum is open from 8.30 am to 12 noon and again from 2 pm to 5 pm. review_text: You are in Andaman so you unless you never left your room, you've seen sea-life in some form. This museum houses shells, corals and aquarium. You can watch whole thing in 30 minutes. Advisable to not waste time going through museums in Port Blair. Tickets 10/-, Camera 20/-

title: Dont miss it
review_text:
Dont miss it. WIll be amazed to see the variety of marine-life we could ever imagine. 
A small one, but with loads of info. The exhibits are minimal but were carefully chosen to keep the interest of the people.

title: If you wont scuba dive or snorkel, or even take a glass boat ride visit this place
review_text:
I saw the same fishes in the museum, same corals in different places in port blair like the aquarium. 

If you are snorkelling or scuba diving this place will perhaps tell you about the fishes you'll be seeing. and i actually remembered all the names when i was snorkelling when i saw them in the ocean.

title: Balas Samudrika Marine Museum
review_text: This Museum is within Portblair and we reached by our tourist taxi. We enjoyed the garden which is very well maintained. There is a skeleton of a huge blue whale displayed in the garden, models of tribals of Andaman & Nicobar Islands which show their appearance,dresses. Inside the museum there are several types of corals, shells displayed in showcases which we have not seen any where else. Our visit to this Museum was highly educative and helped us to improve our awareness about sea animals. There were also miniature Eco huts where tribals live in Andaman & Nicobar islands. There is a shopping counter inside the Museum where I purchased a sea pearl, got fixed to my Ring, the shop keeper was very friendly. One can buy neckwears, ear studs, fresh pearls/ necklaces etc. More

title: a reasonable museum
review_text: This is a very average museum. There is nothing much interesting here. The exhibits are very limited and very average. More over there is no one to take you through this place.

title: Good displays
review_text: Good display of corals and history.. Fish display should be more informative. More history can be included for interested folks and children

title: Ok place to visit
review_text: We were not very museums fan so not that we didn't like this place, it was ok to visit once and to see. There are many museums in PB but this is one of the best in them

title: Get full history & geography
review_text: It is a very good museum. It is maintained by the Navy. It is a must visit place. Each room is educative. Do not hurry. Go over each room.

title: Educational for your kids
review_text: A small but nice museum . Excellent collection of corals and shells . Must take your children here . Despite of ban in photography in aquarium area , people were still clicking photos , need a strict monitoring

title: Informational but limited
review_text:
After diving we were more then interested to see the museum and enjoyed the time spent there. Detailed explanation is given about all the exhibits.The turtle shells , the biggest i saw till date , were awesome. 

It will be a great experience if more fishes , corals are included. 

As per our knowledge the museum closes by 4:30 P.M . The visit should be planned accordingly.

title: Very Informative!
review_text: The Museum is being well maintained.It gives us first hand information about marine life.There are so many types of corals,conch shells,fishes to watch out for.Detailed explanation is given about all the exhibits. We are enlightened on the treasures of the Andaman sea. One needs to allot ample time to gain knowledge about marine life.There is also a small shop selling gift articles.

title: Interesting & Educational
review_text:
A good way of enlightening oneself about da various mar and uder treasures of da island! 
Interesting Xhibits include a skeleton of blue whale...,huge number of shells,colourful fishes in da aquarium etc!!! 
Not to be missed !!

title: Stunning
review_text: Amazing corals, crustaceans, fishes and turtles. Unlike the fishery museum most of these are models except for the fishes. Thanks to Indian Navy for donating some of the awesome exhibits including 3 turtle shells.

title: Just A Museum
review_text: Good place for those who interest in visiting museums and specially for kids. All museums in Portblair are similar. Don not waste your full day for visiting local sight seeing

title: Nice and well maintained museum
review_text: This is a good museum with lot of information on Andaman and Nicobar, sea life, corals and some real species of fishes. History about Andaman and various tribes. One can very easily spend 1-2 hrs here.

title: Good to see
review_text: Samudrika Museum is a good museum with ample of information on marine life – types of fishes, corals, shells etc. If you remember the details seen here, you can discover many of these while you snorkel in Havelock.

title: Samudrika Museum- Visit before snorkelling
review_text: A nicely maintained marine museum. One should visit this place first before snorkeling/ scuba diving as it will give a good idea of corals and marine life to expect. Traveler can then appreciate what he is actually seeing during the diving experience.e

title: Dont miss this
review_text: This was a surprise highlight of the trip. This is an amazing museum, very well catalogued. It taught us a lot about the marine life in the Andaman & Nicobar isalnda and also about the tribal polulation

title: Our little known marine heritage
review_text:
Do visit! 

This small but beautiful museum shows India's and Andaman & Nicobar's rich marine heritage and beauty through a good audio-visual documentary and installation.

title: Could have been better
review_text: Well it shows lot of things you havent seen but it seems more like child education centre rather than a tourist place.

title: Start with this place only
review_text: If you are planning to travel Andaman Island, you start with visiting this place only. You will be able to know what you have to see and when when you see in real, you will know why I see it. Good place. Never miss.

title: excellent overview of marine life in the islands
review_text: Wow. this museum is small but packed with exhibits on ecology of the islands and oceans, shells, fish, corals, etc. I spent just 45 min here and left with a much better idea of the natural beauty of the islands. Highly recommended!

title: glimpse of Andaman and Nicobar
review_text:
You can see sea creatures ,shells and purchase shell items from there. 
it can be covered in 15 to 30 min 
Ticket is cheap around 10 rs

title: worth visiting ......
review_text:
If you like seeing corals and different kind of shells then visit this place , also there is some other interesting information related to Navy worth seeing . The contents of shells and corals are the same as that of Aquarium situated near the water sports complex . 
but worth visiting the museum it will not take more then 1 hr to see it . The museum will be closed on Monday and Government holidays .

title: Decent
review_text: Its like a mix of the anthropological museum and the aquarium. Better than both of them but again its more about the Navy.

title: good place
review_text:
If you have spare time and nothing to do in Port Blair then you can go here. It is a very well maintained place but most things shown there do not entertain the visitor much but you can still go there. 
I am wondering that how can a government place be so well maintained.

title: a bonus with kids
review_text: my son liked it.my daughter did not enter.if u want to see star fish and like coral, visit again.kids..they enjoy.

title: Should Visit
review_text: You can see beautiful creatures in the sea there in the museum. Corals are awesome. When you do snorkling, you might have seen many creatures, you can find the names of those and can have a close watch also in this museum.

title: Okay Okay..!!
review_text: If you have seen enough of Hollywood movies.. Nothing will really excite you in here. Some models of Coral reeves and marine life.

title: Samudrika Marine museum....
review_text:
Samudrika Marine Museum is good place to visit....here you may know how the marine is and was maintained by the Coast guards... 
You may also found the small navy jet there....awesome experience there...

title: Small but interesting Museum
review_text:
It is known as Naval Marine Museum "Samudrika". 
They have well maintained the place, there is brief history of Islands with paintings, pictures, shells, corals, models etc. They have decent collection of shells and corals found around Islands. Place is neat and clean with a proper sitting area before you enters the rooms containing different objects etc. 
Photography is not allowed in some parts of museum, else you can take pictures. The small garden in front of main building is maintained. 
Though there are not too many things and museum itself is a small place in comparison to different museums all around the world but it is worth visiting this place to get a brief introduction to the island and its flora and fona. 
Don't go with high expectations and enjoys the things on the display. More

title: Very well maintained and a good place to start day trip
review_text: This is a good place to start the trip as it is just across the road from Andaman Teal house which the starting point of all day trip buses.This also gives a good introduction to what to expect from the beaches and ecosystem in and around Andaman.The shells , corals were breathtaking.

title: Marine History & Life
review_text: Liked the different rooms that clearly categorize what you are looking at. The information is usful, though how much you'll carry back home is questionable. Children will like the fishes and you'll be amazed by the size and shapes of the corals and shells. Didn't like the fact that they charge you extra for a camera, as there is no security inside and people who haven't paid are still clicking away. Has a small souvenior shop where you could get some interesting knick knacks for people back home.

title: get a glimpse of andaman here
review_text: also known as naval museum.this place is worth visiting.entry fee is Rs20.closing time 5pm.it is opposite to andaman teal house.here you will get to know about geography/geology of andaman,its marine life including fishes,corals,sea shells and about different tribes living here.this museum is well maintained.neat and clean.a small souvenir shop is also there.

title: IT IS ALSO KNOWN AS NAVAL MARINE MUSEUM!!!!!!
review_text: Samudrika is under the administration of the navy. The Samudrika is therefore also referred to as the Naval Marine Museum.The Samudrika is particularly famous for an exquisite collection of shells, corals and other significant specimens of the marine life typical of these islands. Other than shells and corals, one can also find a good collection of fishes of different colors.One can visit the Samudrika from 8.30 am to 12 noon and again from 2 pm to 5 pm. The museum remains closed on all national holidays as well as Mondays.The Samudrika is located on the opposite side of Andaman Teal House in Delanipur.The Samudrika Marine Museum has five sections(rooms)-background of Andaman Islands, Geographical information, people of Andaman, Archeology and lastly the Marine lifestyle. In all rooms you can click pics but except in the room where fishes are kept.There is one curio corner inside the campus of the museum from where you can do your shopping(it's cheap compared to the private shops near to sagarika emporium). review_text: Got comprehensive knowledge about Andaman & Nicobar Islands, all data, flora and fauna, people and tribes...everything that you may want to know about A&N at one place under one roof.

title: time pass
review_text: giving it a miss if you has something else to do.there was hardly anything worthwhile to see.

title: It is OK
review_text: Considering the state of the A&N administered fisheries museum this is a really well done museum. If you consider some of the marine museums abroad this pales in comparison but some of the exhibits are worth the time you will spend here. Please do not buy camera tickets. I paid for three cameras but did not find anything worth photographing.
